We are asked to find the limit of a combination of functions.

Therefore, we will have to use a couple of key facts about limits of combined functions:

Given functions $u$ and $v$ and an $x$-value $c$ such that the limits $\displaystyle\lim_{x\to c}u(x)$ and $\displaystyle\lim_{x\to c}v(x)$ exist **and** $\displaystyle\lim_{x\to c}v(x)\neq0$, then...

$\displaystyle\lim_{x\to c}\dfrac{u(x)}{v(x)}=\dfrac{\displaystyle\lim_{x\to c}u(x)}{\displaystyle\lim_{x\to c}v(x)}$

According to their graphs, $\displaystyle\lim_{x\to 0}h(x)$ and $\displaystyle\lim_{x\to 0}g(x)$ exist:

- $\displaystyle\lim_{x\to 0}h(x)=\greenD 4$


- $\displaystyle\lim_{x\to 0}g(x)=\purpleC 0$ 

![graph](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f65334ea1e4d8977131b8f9fca9d97613f84f5ba) ![graph](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7fc9eb569c59c6b26683341169a197f802a4e455)

However, the above property only holds if the limit of the function in the denominator isn't equal to $0$.

In our case, the limit of $g$ is in the denominator and it *is* equal to $0$.
